title: 104_s978
content:
The "Charitable Giving Protection Act of 1995" includes amendments to securities laws and clarification of antitrust laws. The Act is divided into two titles, with specific sections outlining the amendments and exemptions. The Congress recognizes the vital role of charities in meeting the needs of the American people and aims to support charitable giving without excessive government intervention. The Technical Corrections Act of 1988 distinguished between charitable gift annuities and for-profit annuities. Charitable gift annuities, unlike commercial annuities, are not issued for profit by charities and are not subject to antitrust laws. AMENDMENT TO THE INVESTMENT COMPANY ACT OF 1940. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph allowing charitable organizations to maintain pooled income funds for collective investment and reinvestment of various assets. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow charitable organizations to maintain pooled income funds for collective investment and reinvestment of assets, with specific conditions for exclusion from treatment as an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow charitable organizations to maintain pooled income funds for collective investment and reinvestment of assets, with specific conditions for exclusion from treatment as an investment company. The instruments governing the operation of the pooled income fund require compliance by June 30, 1996, or the date of investment, and individuals soliciting gifts for collective trust funds must be volunteers or employed in fundraising activities without receiving commissions based on gift amounts. The exemption for maintaining a trust or fund by a charitable organization will end on December 31, 1998. The terms 'pooled income fund' and 'charitable organization' are defined within the context of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The terms 'charitable lead trust', 'charitable remainder trust', and 'charitable gift annuity' are defined within the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 102 amends the Securities Act of 1933 by adding a new paragraph regarding securities issued by certain funds. SEC. 103 makes amendments to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 102 amends the Securities Act of 1933 by adding a new paragraph regarding securities issued by certain funds. Amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 exempts certain securities and fund interests from broker-dealer provisions. The new paragraph exempts charitable organizations and their trustees, directors, officers, employees, or volunteers from being classified as brokers or dealers solely for buying, holding, selling, or trading securities on behalf of the organization. The new paragraph exempts charitable organizations, funds exempt from the Investment Company Act of 1940, and trusts or donative instruments whose assets can be contributed to such funds. SEC. 104 amends the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. Section 202(a)(11) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exclude banks, lawyers, brokers, publishers, and other specified individuals or entities. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exclude certain individuals and entities, including charitable organizations and their trustees, directors, officers, employees, and volunteers providing advice only to specific entities exempt from the Act. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 excludes certain individuals and entities, including charitable organizations and their trustees, from being subject to the Act. This includes those who may contribute to or invest in funds according to specific regulations. SEC. 105. EFFECTIVE DATES AND APPLICABILITY. This title and its amendments apply to all pending and future administrative and judicial actions as a defense against claims under various securities acts. SEC. 106. PREEMPTION OF STATE LAW. (a) Registration Requirements.--Securities exempt under section 3(c)(7) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 are exempt from state registration laws. (b) Treatment of Charitable Organizations.--Charitable organizations and their personnel are not required to register as dealers, brokers, agents, or investment advisers solely for trading securities on their own behalf. The section allows capacity as trustee or administrator for charitable organizations, funds exempt under section 3(c)(7) of the Investment Company Act of 1940, or trusts with assets that can be invested in such funds. States can enact laws that do not preempt this section for 3 years. Definitions are provided for clarity. Definitions for this section include "charitable organization" as described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, "security" as defined in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and "State" referring to various regions within the United States. TITLE II--CLARIFICATION OF ANTITRUST LAWS

SEC. 201. EXEMPTION FROM ANTITRUST LAWS. Charitable organizations are exempt from antitrust laws regarding charitable gift annuities. Antitrust laws include the Sherman Act, Clayton Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, and similar State laws. Charitable organizations are defined as those described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. In 1986, a charitable gift annuity is defined as an annuity issued by a charitable organization under section 501(m)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States. States have the option to enact laws that do not preempt this section for a 3-year period after the enactment of this Act. The exemption in section 201 of the Act applies to any legal action before or after the enactment date, serving as a defense against antitrust law claims related to charitable gift annuities.
